intro: Chamaecladon truncatum, commonly known as the mountain sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial shrub characterized by its compact growth habit and small, narrow leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Chamaecladon truncatum is often found in rocky habitats and is valued for its drought tolerance and ornamental appeal.
